revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-28 16:52:30.000000000', 'message': 'Retry "lvs" call on segfault for _get_thin_pool_free_space

This is a follow-up to I6824ba4f.

LVM commands segfault occasionally, exiting with code 139.
Change I6824ba4f introduced a workaround to retry the command
when code 139 is returned, which generally works.  This expands
that retry to the case where thin pool space is queried, which
currently results in the LVM driver reporting no free space to
the scheduler.

Further work is needed to expand this to other LVM calls, but
this patch is narrow in scope to target a particular gate
failure.

Related-Bug: #1901783
Partial-Bug: #1932188
Closes-Bug: #1932287
Change-Id: I0a2420f3e4a411f5fa52ebe2d22859b138ef387f
(cherry picked from commit 410306efb82760191e76b4d40817f38842d87eb0)
(cherry picked from commit 9ad46817e42b577ae2625ce90a32ee96eb00f427)
'}]
commit_message:
Retry "lvs" call on segfault for _get_thin_pool_free_space

This is a follow-up to I6824ba4f.

LVM commands segfault occasionally, exiting with code 139.
Change I6824ba4f introduced a workaround to retry the command
when code 139 is returned, which generally works.  This expands
that retry to the case where thin pool space is queried, which
currently results in the LVM driver reporting no free space to
the scheduler.

Further work is needed to expand this to other LVM calls, but
this patch is narrow in scope to target a particular gate
failure.

Related-Bug: #1901783
Partial-Bug: #1932188
Closes-Bug: #1932287
Change-Id: I0a2420f3e4a411f5fa52ebe2d22859b138ef387f
(cherry picked from commit 410306efb82760191e76b4d40817f38842d87eb0)
(cherry picked from commit 9ad46817e42b577ae2625ce90a32ee96eb00f427)

stable/wallaby.

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-29 17:00:01.000000000', 'message': '[OVN] Do not fail when processing SG rule deletion

When a security group rule deletion command is issued, before executing
the database operations, a "BEFORE_DELETE" event is raised.

The OVN handler attending to this event should not fail if the security
group rule does not exist; the database transaction [1]  will in case of
not finding it, raising the correct exception and HTTP 404 error:

  Jun 29 16:58:28 dev20 neutron-server[8820]: INFO neutron.wsgi [None \
    req-1821ec9f-2439-420b-80eb-1138896de865 demo admin] 192.168.10.70 \
    "GET /v2.0/security-group-rules/missing_sg_rule_example HTTP/1.1" \
    status: 404 len: 348 time: 0.0352871

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/6196c0873b4af9abd9055bf92478ff05ae090104/neutron/db/securitygroups_db.py#L858-L868

Change-Id: I58f6e5b309e089f6681d2c4bbff4ff7fda96435f
Closes-Bug: #1933638
'}]
commit_message:
[OVN] Do not fail when processing SG rule deletion

When a security group rule deletion command is issued, before executing
the database operations, a "BEFORE_DELETE" event is raised.

The OVN handler attending to this event should not fail if the security
group rule does not exist; the database transaction [1]  will in case of
not finding it, raising the correct exception and HTTP 404 error:

  Jun 29 16:58:28 dev20 neutron-server[8820]: INFO neutron.wsgi [None \
    req-1821ec9f-2439-420b-80eb-1138896de865 demo admin] 192.168.10.70 \
    "GET /v2.0/security-group-rules/missing_sg_rule_example HTTP/1.1" \
    status: 404 len: 348 time: 0.0352871

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/6196c0873b4af9abd9055bf92478ff05ae090104/neutron/db/securitygroups_db.py#L858-L868

Change-Id: I58f6e5b309e089f6681d2c4bbff4ff7fda96435f
Closes-Bug: #1933638

commit_message:
puppet: Create ocata/pike-eol tag for puppet-openstack-integration

The stable/ocata branch and the stable/pike branch of puppet repos
have been EOLed[1]. This creates eol tags for p-o-i repo so that we
can retire Ocata and Pike for that repo as well.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/releases/+/726392/

Change-Id: If30309b3c432e29bf0b9854694a3280ba4527689

subject: Make property values on delete more robust
messages:
[{'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-04 01:00:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-05 19:54:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-05 22:10:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-08 15:11:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2021-06-18 06:00:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

We can also update these: https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/heat/engine/resources/openstack/heat/value.py#L68
https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/heat/engine/resources/openstack/heat/instance_group.py#L241
As they also use properties only'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2021-06-30 14:46:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2
> 
> We can also update these: https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/heat/engine/resources/openstack/heat/value.py#L68
> https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/heat/engine/resources/openstack/heat/instance_group.py#L241
> As they also use properties only

I don't think that's necessary, as they're not used during deletion.

On forward transitions through the dependency graph (i.e. update nodes) we pass along all of the attributes of the resource that are referenced to the next resource, so they're always available.
The issue is that on reverse transitions (i.e. cleanup nodes) we don't (can't) do that, so if we don't have stored values then we have to do something else. Previously that was falling back to returning None from GetAtt(), but this patch moves that handling elsewhere.

Both of those examples could be changed, but they don't _have_ to be. The context manager is actually a bit of a hacky solution; it's used in the Resource class so that individual plugins can continue to reference self.properties and do the Right Thing. I think I'd prefer not to start using it in the plugins and stick with frozen_definition(), which is a bit more explicit."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-04 01:00:14.000000000', 'message': "Make property values on delete more robust

When deleting a resource, we set its property values to the stored values
from the last update (since fc77e432978334687e143f0a8e8d69a14df2de1d) if we
know them.

This can return data that is not altogether meaningful in convergence when
there are no stored property values. Since we don't load every resource in
the stack in order to do the delete, we won't be able to get refids or
attributes from other resources. Any attributes will be replaced with None
based on special handling in the GetAtt function(s) that checks the status
of the target resource and gets back a completely bogus INIT_COMPLETE. We
wish to remove this special handling, but cannot do so without causing
errors.

Even when we have the stored property values, we can run into the same
issue because calling frozen_definition() has the side effect of also
trying the resolve e.g. metadata, even though we don't need that data.

Read only the frozen properties when they are available, and suppress
errors accessing the live properties when they are not. Since the
frozen_properties() decorator potentially suffers from the same issue (e.g.
during a signal), implement the fixes there and reuse it for the delete.

Change-Id: I6e23f326790e13a3fcb9eecfae8eb9327bbe33ba
Story: #2003915
Task: 26888
"}, {'created': '2018-10-05 22:10:07.000000000', 'message': "Make property values on delete more robust

When deleting a resource, we set its property values to the stored values
from the last update (since fc77e432978334687e143f0a8e8d69a14df2de1d) if we
know them.

This can return data that is not altogether meaningful in convergence when
there are no stored property values. Since we don't load every resource in
the stack in order to do the delete, we won't be able to get refids or
attributes from other resources. Any attributes will be replaced with None
based on special handling in the GetAtt function(s) that checks the status
of the target resource and gets back a completely bogus INIT_COMPLETE. We
wish to remove this special handling, but cannot do so without causing
errors.

Even when we have the stored property values, we can run into the same
issue because calling frozen_definition() has the side effect of also
trying the resolve e.g. metadata, even though we don't need that data.

Read only the frozen properties when they are available, and suppress
errors accessing the live properties when they are not. Since the
frozen_properties() decorator potentially suffers from the same issue (e.g.
during a signal), implement the fixes there and reuse it for the delete.

Change-Id: I6e23f326790e13a3fcb9eecfae8eb9327bbe33ba
Story: #2003915
Task: 26888
"}]
commit_message:
Make property values on delete more robust

When deleting a resource, we set its property values to the stored values
from the last update (since fc77e432978334687e143f0a8e8d69a14df2de1d) if we
know them.

This can return data that is not altogether meaningful in convergence when
there are no stored property values. Since we don't load every resource in
the stack in order to do the delete, we won't be able to get refids or
attributes from other resources. Any attributes will be replaced with None
based on special handling in the GetAtt function(s) that checks the status
of the target resource and gets back a completely bogus INIT_COMPLETE. We
wish to remove this special handling, but cannot do so without causing
errors.

Even when we have the stored property values, we can run into the same
issue because calling frozen_definition() has the side effect of also
trying the resolve e.g. metadata, even though we don't need that data.

Read only the frozen properties when they are available, and suppress
errors accessing the live properties when they are not. Since the
frozen_properties() decorator potentially suffers from the same issue (e.g.
during a signal), implement the fixes there and reuse it for the delete.

Change-Id: I6e23f326790e13a3fcb9eecfae8eb9327bbe33ba
Story: #2003915
Task: 26888

https://juju.is/docs/offline-mode-strategies#heading--juju-specific-proxy'}, {'account_id': 20635, 'date': '2020-07-28 16:25:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 24824, 'date': '2020-09-15 12:10:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 24824, 'date': '2021-06-28 08:06:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

See my comment @419 with reasoning for the -1:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-glance-simplestreams-sync/+/743022/3/files/glance_simplestreams_sync.py#419

I really think that sstream-mirror-glance should support accepting proxy options as command-line options because otherwise we force our users to maintain a NO_PROXY list which does not allow for CIDR usage in a general case. As a result, this list needs to contain all addresses and hostnames for which HTTP(s) communication needs to bypass the proxy. With large subnets a large CSV list requires more memory than the default 8MiB limit of stack memory for processes.

https://git.launchpad.net/simplestreams/tree/bin/sstream-mirror-glance?h=ubuntu/devel'}, {'account_id': 11683, 'date': '2021-06-30 14:44:17.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning to allow someone else to provide a solution.'}]

Closes-Bug: 1843486

For standalone CA we delegate all tasks to pki_setup_host. But in order
to use crypto collection, cryptography library needs to be present.

To ensure that this dependency is satisfied, deployer can provide

Change-Id: Ia44e5512fbf79271ff6cc98d0b974edb1f84a4ff

commit_message:
Add pki_setup_host_python_interpreter variable

For standalone CA we delegate all tasks to pki_setup_host. But in order
to use crypto collection, cryptography library needs to be present.

To ensure that this dependency is satisfied, deployer can provide
path to python binary (ie venv) where it will be present.

Change-Id: Ia44e5512fbf79271ff6cc98d0b974edb1f84a4ff
(cherry picked from commit c4a87bb964b4cebe9f56fe0d499580d021df75a5)

Cutting the wallaby stable branch.

branches.

imported to new location now and supposed to be retired from
openstack/namespace[1].

-https://review.opendev.org/#/c/744110/

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-June/015647.html

commit_message:
Dropping lower constraints testing (stable Stein)

This topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

As decided in Neutron meeting, stable branches will drop this
CI job [2].
For stable/rocky and older in Neutron meeting ([3]) the decision was to
make non-voting and faulty jobs (see [4]) dropped.

[1]http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html
[2]http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/networking/2021/networking.2021-01-12-14.00.log.html

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-25 11:02:22.000000000', 'message': 'Run resources in pre_network_* before network configurations

This is a prep work to restore the previous behavior to run
ExtraConfigPre and NodeExtraConfig before network configratuons,
and implements a hook to run all resources defined in the pre_network_*
hostvar.

All tasks which are supposed to be executed before network
configurations will be defined in this hostvar by later change in
tripleo-common.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/772303
Related-Bug: #1907214
Change-Id: I96e7e4c570839cfba6011788464d8e93925b2f01
'}, {'created': '2021-01-26 07:29:08.000000000', 'message': 'Restore PreNetworkConfig resources

This change restores the PreNetworkConfig resources, so that we migrate
back ExtraCnfigPre and NodeExtraConfig from pre network configurations
to post network configurations, to be consistent with older version
depending on Heat software deployments instead of config download.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/772303
Related-Bug: #1907214
Change-Id: I96e7e4c570839cfba6011788464d8e93925b2f01
'}, {'created': '2021-02-01 05:57:03.000000000', 'message': 'Restore PreNetworkConfig resources

This change restores the PreNetworkConfig resources, so that we migrate
back ExtraCnfigPre and NodeExtraConfig from pre network configurations

'}]
commit_message:
Restore PreNetworkConfig resources

This change restores the PreNetworkConfig resources, so that we migrate
back ExtraCnfigPre and NodeExtraConfig from pre network configurations
to post network configurations, to be consistent with older version
depending on Heat software deployments instead of config download.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/772303
Closes-Bug: #1907214
Change-Id: I96e7e4c570839cfba6011788464d8e93925b2f01

commit_message:
[check_cpu] Remove README.md file

This patch removes the README.md file and adds the documentation
directly in the sphinx role documentation index. All variables have been
commented with a proper description to be included automatically in the
sphinx build.

Change-Id: Icc9581821b5ba9c2bef7c0608d989e7044017ae6
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>

subject: Expose ``user visible`` extra specs
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4523, 'name': 'Eric Harney', 'email': 'eharney@redhat.com', 'username': 'eharney'}, {'_account_id': 5314, 'name': 'Brian Rosmaita', 'email': 'rosmaita.fossdev@gmail.com', 'username': 'brian-rosmaita'}, {'_account_id': 7198, 'name': 'Jay Bryant', 'email': 'jungleboyj@electronicjungle.net', 'username': 'jsbryant'}, {'_account_id': 9555, 'name': 'Matthew Booth', 'email': 'mbooth@redhat.com', 'username': 'MatthewBooth'}, {'_account_id': 13425, 'name': 'Simon Dodsley', 'email': 'simon@purestorage.com', 'username': 'sdodsley'}, {'_account_id': 21129, 'name': 'Alan Bishop', 'email': 'abishop@redhat.com', 'username': 'ASBishop'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 27615, 'name': 'Rajat Dhasmana', 'email': 'rajatdhasmana@gmail.com', 'username': 'whoami-rajat'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-13 20:21:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2021-06-14 14:39:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-15 11:24:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

Thanks Alan! I agree with your review comments.'}, {'account_id': 27615, 'date': '2021-06-16 01:48:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-16 02:17:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(8 comments)

Thanks for the review Rajesh, especially for the careful attention to the extra spec names.  I'm not sure about using 'project visible' rather than 'tenant visible', especially in our new world with Domain and System columns alongside Project, but I'm not dug in about it.  I chose 'tenant' as the traditional term for the concept of non-administrative users of the cloud.  But I'm open to using whatever terminology the Cinder community thinks best.

Assuming we can get that straightened out, I think the main task will be (as abishop noted) to enumerate a clear set of tenant/project visible extra specs that will be exposed to non administrative users with the new microversion.  These should be abstract, backend independent, and indicate features or capabilities that a regular user needs to know in order for their volume creates not to be successful.  If you can help us identify these (I'm a bit stale on Cinder), that would be very helpful."}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-16 12:12:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Since in the old days 'tenant' was used in keystone for what is now called 'project', we'll need to guard against the interpretation that what we really mean here are project-scoped extra specs.  What we intend instead are extra specs that are (also) visible to non-admins.  This is a matter of keystone role, rather than of keystone scope.  The idea is that there is a subset of abstract, backend-independent extra specs that should be visible to all the keystone roles, to members and readers as well as administrators.  We have been putting the point by saying they would be visible to tenants, the users who rent or are granted use of the infrastructure but who do not own the infrastructure or administer it on behalf of the owners."}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2021-06-16 12:49:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I see both sides:

1. Tenant visible is meant to convey the specs are visible to everyone, and not just admins
2. In its traditional context the term "tenant" is deprecated in favor of "project"

"Project visible" satisfies 2, but at the expense of 1.

What do people think of using the term "member visible?" I feel is satisfies 1 without running afoul of 2.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-16 14:21:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> I see both sides:
> 
> 1. Tenant visible is meant to convey the specs are visible to everyone, and not just admins
> 2. In its traditional context the term "tenant" is deprecated in favor of "project"
> 
> "Project visible" satisfies 2, but at the expense of 1.
> 
> What do people think of using the term "member visible?" I feel is satisfies 1 without running afoul of 2.

I'm OK with member_visible but note that in the prototype patch the extra specs are visible to all roles (including reader) and that's the way I think it should be.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-17 12:02:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(6 comments)

New revision on the way, thanks for the helpful comments!'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-17 12:11:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2021-06-17 19:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 13425, 'date': '2021-06-17 19:54:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-06-18 13:50:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Basically looks good, but there are a few questions I'd like you to address."}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2021-06-18 14:17:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2021-06-18 15:51:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

This looks good to me. I would be able to implement ReadWriteMany support in OpenShift for cinder backends based on this.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-19 19:48:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(5 comments)

A few followup remarks inline.'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2021-06-21 14:29:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2021-06-21 18:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 13425, 'date': '2021-06-21 19:07:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2021-06-21 19:36:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-06-22 05:02:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

The tl;dr for this is: I don't think we need an mv bump for this spec, but we do need a new policy.

These are the current policies we have that are relevant to extra-specs.

(1) volume_extension:access_types_extra_specs
"List or show volume type with extra specs attribute"
Adds extra_specs to the following responses:
    GET  /types/{type_id}
    GET  /types

(The ability to make the GET /types/* API calls is governed by other policies.)

(2) volume_extension:types_extra_specs:index
"List type extra specs"
    GET  /types/{type_id}/extra_specs

(3) volume_extension:types_extra_specs:show
"Show one specified type extra specs"
    GET  /types/{type_id}/extra_specs/{extra_spec_key}

(4) volume_extension:types_extra_specs:create
"Create type extra specs"
    POST  /types/{type_id}/extra_specs

(5) volume_extension:types_extra_specs:update
"Update type extra specs"
    PUT  /types/{type_id}/extra_specs/{extra_spec_key}

(6) volume_extension:types_extra_specs:delete
"Delete type extra specs"
    DELETE  /types/{type_id}/extra_specs/{extra_spec_key}


(I'll state here that we don't want to rely on an "administrative context" to determine whether content is displayed or not.  That has introduced problems in other calls, and is what the "consistent and secure RBAC" effort is trying to eliminate.)

I think what we need to do for this spec is to add an additional policy, named something like 'volume_extension:types_extra_specs:read_sensitive' ("RS" for short)

Given "multiattach" as nonsensitive and "volume_backend_name" as sensitive:

- user A who satisfies volume_extension:access_types_extra_specs (but NOT RS) will see an "extra_specs" element in the volume-type response containing "multiattach".
- user B who satisfies volume_extension:access_types_extra_specs AND RS will see the full "extra_specs" element containing both "multiattach" and "volume_backend_name" in the volume-type response.

"List type extra specs" (GET  /types/{type_id}/extra_specs) can be handled the same way, i.e., if you have permission to make the call, you see only the nonsensitive extra-specs in the response, and if you also have RS, you see the full list of extra-specs.

The default for volume_extension:types_extra_specs:read_sensitive will be admin-only.

I don't think we need a microversion bump because the API requests/responses aren't being changed at all.

We probably ship with:

volume_extension:types_extra_specs:read_sensitive : admin-only
volume_extension:access_types_extra_specs : admin-only
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:index : admin-only
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:show : admin-only
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:create : admin-only
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:update : admin-only
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:delete : admin-only

And then the behavior is the same as current behavior.  Also, that's why I think there is no point having a mv bump for this, because with the above settings, there is no difference between the pre-bump and post-bump API responses.  Whether someone sees the non-sensitive extra-specs or not depends on how the operator has configured policies, regardless of what API version is requested.

Or, we can ship with:

volume_extension:types_extra_specs:read_sensitive : admin-only
volume_extension:access_types_extra_specs : any authorized user
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:index : any authorized user
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:show : any authorized user
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:create : admin-only
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:update : admin-only
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:delete : admin-only

Even with the "new" behavior, I don't see the point of an mv bump because the new mv can be completely negated if the operator so chooses.  Also, the behavior isn't really new because the API responses haven't changed.

The tricky thing will be how to handle
    GET  /types/{type_id}/extra_specs/{extra_spec_key}
but we basically do what you outlined in the spec, namely:
(1) must satisfy volume_extension:types_extra_specs:show to make the call
(2) if {extra_spec_key} is in the nonsensitive list, return the value
(3) if {extra_spec_key} exists but is not in the nonsensitive list:
    (3a) if caller satisfies volume_extension:types_extra_specs:read_sensitive then return the value
    (3b) else, return 404
(4) return 404

That doesn't seem too bad.

I think there are no circumstances under which we want a non-admin doing create, update, or delete on extra-specs, so I don't think the RS policy has any role in those operations.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-06-22 05:03:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Forgot to vote.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-22 11:39:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

"We probably ship with:

volume_extension:types_extra_specs:read_sensitive : admin-only
volume_extension:access_types_extra_specs : admin-only
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:index : admin-only
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:show : admin-only
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:create : admin-only
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:update : admin-only
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:delete : admin-only

And then the behavior is the same as current behavior.  Also, that's why I think there is no point having a mv bump for this, because with the above settings, there is no difference between the pre-bump and post-bump API responses.  Whether someone sees the non-sensitive extra-specs or not depends on how the operator has configured policies, regardless of what API version is requested.

Or, we can ship with:

volume_extension:types_extra_specs:read_sensitive : admin-only
volume_extension:access_types_extra_specs : any authorized user
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:index : any authorized user
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:show : any authorized user
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:create : admin-only
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:update : admin-only
volume_extension:types_extra_specs:delete : admin-only"

I strongly advocate for shipping with a solution that changes the default behavior.  Just making a new behavior possible via policy but not changing it -- at a new release, with doc and release note even if no microversion bump -- doesn't really solve the problem because it requires cloud administrators to make an active change to do something that (in hindsight) Cinder should have been doing all along.
Many administrators won't know to do it or bother to read that they should do it and their clouds will remain broken with respect to the use cases that drive this spec.

I'll leave it to Cinder folks whether a new microversion is required when the default REST API *behavior* (expected responses) changes.  In Manila I think we would bump it even if the syntactic form of the responses isn't changed if the semantics are new.'}, {'account_id': 13425, 'date': '2021-06-22 11:58:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I tend to agree that we should turn this on by default.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-06-22 13:58:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I can go either way on the default settings, let's see what the wider cinder community thinks.

About the microversioning: I'm not sure how we could make that work given the current policies.

Suppose the change described in this spec is mv 3.77.
The policy "volume_extension:access_types_extra_specs" is set to any authorized user (was previously admin only).
If a "regular" user requests mv 3.76, they get the full extra specs.
If a "regular" user requests mv 3.77, they get only the non-sensitive extra-specs.
We certainly don't want that to be the case.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-22 15:18:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Patch Set 4:
> 
> I can go either way on the default settings, let's see what the wider cinder community thinks.
> 
> About the microversioning: I'm not sure how we could make that work given the current policies.
> 
> Suppose the change described in this spec is mv 3.77.
> The policy "volume_extension:access_types_extra_specs" is set to any authorized user (was previously admin only).
> If a "regular" user requests mv 3.76, they get the full extra specs.
> If a "regular" user requests mv 3.77, they get only the non-sensitive extra-specs.
> We certainly don't want that to be the case.

Right, we wouldn't want to return any extra-specs, sensitive or not, at 3.76 or earlier.

To deal with this (and we should be more explicit in the spec) you check on the request's microversion when building the view so that at less than 3.77 you do not return *any* extra-specs to non-admin users and at 3.77 and greater you return user-visible extra-specs to non-admin users.

Nova and Manila already check request microversions and return different views as a function of these.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-22 17:48:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Patch Set 4:
> 
> > Patch Set 4:
> > 
> > I can go either way on the default settings, let's see what the wider cinder community thinks.
> > 
> > About the microversioning: I'm not sure how we could make that work given the current policies.
> > 
> > Suppose the change described in this spec is mv 3.77.
> > The policy "volume_extension:access_types_extra_specs" is set to any authorized user (was previously admin only).
> > If a "regular" user requests mv 3.76, they get the full extra specs.
> > If a "regular" user requests mv 3.77, they get only the non-sensitive extra-specs.
> > We certainly don't want that to be the case.
> 
> Right, we wouldn't want to return any extra-specs, sensitive or not, at 3.76 or earlier.
> 
> To deal with this (and we should be more explicit in the spec) you check on the request's microversion when building the view so that at less than 3.77 you do not return *any* extra-specs to non-admin users and at 3.77 and greater you return user-visible extra-specs to non-admin users.
> 
> Nova and Manila already check request microversions and return different views as a function of these.

I should say explicitly I agree with Brian about using policy rather than context.is_admin to check whether the request is from an admin user.  Updated the prototype https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/797170 accordingly.  Can put an example there of microversion check when building the API response view if that would be useful.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-06-22 17:57:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Can put an example there of microversion check when building the API response view if that would be useful.

It's not necessary.  I understand the concept.  I just think it's pointless because it's going to give counterintuitive results for the GET /types/{type_id} and GET /types/{type_id}/{key} responses, because the new policy defaults will allow you to make them no matter what mv you're using, but if you ask for mv 3.76, you'll get an empty response."}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-22 18:14:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Patch Set 4:
> 
> > Can put an example there of microversion check when building the API response view if that would be useful.

I just think it's pointless because it's going to give counterintuitive results for the GET /types/{type_id} and GET /types/{type_id}/{key} responses, because the new policy defaults will allow you to make them no matter what mv you're using, but if you ask for mv 3.76, you'll get an empty response.

I realize I should have just said earlier on that if we don't need to do the microversion bump for this, then that's great :D"}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2021-06-22 20:00:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2021-06-22 20:05:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-22 20:29:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Expose ``user visible`` extra specs

so that regular users can know the abstract back end
independent capabilities and features in volume types.

Implements: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/expose-user-visible-extra-specs

APIImpact
DocImpact

Co-Authored-By: Tom Barron <tpb@dyncloud.net>
Co-Authored-By: Alan Bishop <abishop@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Id236326dca9ee08aad8427ea6cb400e25e7ac09e

commit_message:
Add pki_setup_host_python_interpreter variable

For standalone CA we delegate all tasks to pki_setup_host. But in order
to use crypto collection, cryptography library needs to be present.

To ensure that this dependency is satisfied, deployer can provide
path to python binary (ie venv) where it will be present.

Change-Id: Ia44e5512fbf79271ff6cc98d0b974edb1f84a4ff

commit_message:
Close session at clean_up if available

To avoid unclosed socket[1] left overs, explicitly
close session at clean_up if available.

[1] sys:1: ResourceWarning: unclosed <socket.socket fd=4>

Story: 2009015
Task: 42735
Related-Bug: #1934098
Change-Id: Idf4865686c37f6f9f61d1f3333b976cc687de9e1

commit_message:
Update master for stable/wallaby

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/wallaby.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/wallaby.

Sem-Ver: feature
Change-Id: I4b5dbd04eeef670f66b567e380cb15cd6547aee6

Closes-Bug: #1933226

commit_message:
Replace deprecated with_lockmode with with_for_update

The Query.with_lockmode() method is deprecated since version 0.9.0
and will be removed in a future release. [1]
This patch replaces it with Query.with_for_update().
The 'faultstring' was been modified to 'Exactly 5 or 6 columns has to be
specified for iterator expression', so adds one space between "iterator"
and "expression" for 'expected_error_msg'.

Also use upper-constraints in doc build to avoid issues in pdf build.

[1]
https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/query.html#sqlalchemy.orm.query.Query.with_lockmode

Closes-Bug: #1933226
Change-Id: I0ad514da647bb08790259fd27e56a41f6dbbbaa0

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-08 13:30:30.000000000', 'message': 'Ceilometer compute `retry_on_disconnect` using `no-wait`

It was discovered a problem on a production setup of Ceilometer compute
with metrics stopping to be gathered. While troubleshooting, we found
the following error message.

```
ERROR ceilometer.polling.manager [-] Prevent pollster cpu from polling
```

That error message happened after the following message:

```
WARNING ceilometer.compute.pollsters [-] Cannot inspect data of
CPUPollster for <UUID>, non-fatal reason: Failed to inspect instance
<UUID> stats, can not get info from libvirt: Unable to read from
monitor: Connection reset by peer: NoDataException: Failed to inspect
instance <UUID> stats, can not get info from libvirt: Unable to read
from monitor: Connection reset by peer
```

The instance was running just fine in the host. It seems a concurrency
issue with some other process that made the instance locked/unavailable
to ceilometer computer pollsters. Ceilometer was unable to connect to
Libvirt (after 2 retries), and the code is designed to prevent
Ceilometer from continuing trying. Therefore, the "CPU" metric pollster
was put in permanent error. To fix the issue, We needed to restart
Ceilometer in the affected hosts. However, until we discovered this
issue, we lost the amount 3 days of data.

```
@libvirt_utils.raise_nodata_if_unsupported
@libvirt_utils.retry_on_disconnect
def inspect_instance(self, instance, duration=None):
    domain = self._get_domain_not_shut_off_or_raise(instance)
```

It will try to retrieve the domain (VM) object (XML description) via
libvirt. If it fails, it will retry via
`@libvirt_utils.retry_on_disconnect`; if that fails, it marks the
metric in permanent error with the annotation:
`@libvirt_utils.raise_nodata_if_unsupported`.

Other metrics continued working. Therefore, I investigated a bit
deeper, and the problem seems to be here:

```
retry_on_disconnect = tenacity.retry(
    retry=tenacity.retry_if_exception(is_disconnection_exception),
    stop=tenacity.stop_after_attempt(2))
```

The `retry_on_disconnect`  annotation is not configuring the "tenacity"
retry library wait. The default is "no wait". Therefore, the retries
have a bigger chance of being affected by very minor instabilities
(microseconds connection issues can generate a problem with this
configuration). One alternative to avoid such problems in the future
is to use a wait configuration such as the one being proposed. Then,
ceilometer computer pollsters would wait/sleep before retrying, which
would provide some time for the system to be available for the compute
pollsters.

In this proposal, we would wait 2^x * 3 seconds between each retry
starting with 1 second, then up to 60 seconds.

Change-Id: I9a2d46f870dc2d2791a7763177773dc0cf8aed9d

commit_message:
Ceilometer compute `retry_on_disconnect` using `no-wait`

It was discovered a problem on a production setup of Ceilometer compute
with metrics stopping to be gathered. While troubleshooting, we found
the following error message.

```
ERROR ceilometer.polling.manager [-] Prevent pollster cpu from polling
```

That error message happened after the following message:

```
WARNING ceilometer.compute.pollsters [-] Cannot inspect data of
CPUPollster for <UUID>, non-fatal reason: Failed to inspect instance
<UUID> stats, can not get info from libvirt: Unable to read from
monitor: Connection reset by peer: NoDataException: Failed to inspect
instance <UUID> stats, can not get info from libvirt: Unable to read
from monitor: Connection reset by peer
```

The instance was running just fine in the host. It seems a concurrency
issue with some other process that made the instance locked/unavailable
to ceilometer computer pollsters. Ceilometer was unable to connect to
Libvirt (after 2 retries), and the code is designed to prevent
Ceilometer from continuing trying. Therefore, the "CPU" metric pollster
was put in permanent error. To fix the issue, We needed to restart
Ceilometer in the affected hosts. However, until we discovered this
issue, we lost the amount 3 days of data.

```
@libvirt_utils.raise_nodata_if_unsupported
@libvirt_utils.retry_on_disconnect
def inspect_instance(self, instance, duration=None):
    domain = self._get_domain_not_shut_off_or_raise(instance)
```

It will try to retrieve the domain (VM) object (XML description) via
libvirt. If it fails, it will retry via
`@libvirt_utils.retry_on_disconnect`; if that fails, it marks the
metric in permanent error with the annotation:
`@libvirt_utils.raise_nodata_if_unsupported`.

Other metrics continued working. Therefore, I investigated a bit
deeper, and the problem seems to be here:

```
retry_on_disconnect = tenacity.retry(
    retry=tenacity.retry_if_exception(is_disconnection_exception),
    stop=tenacity.stop_after_attempt(2))
```

The `retry_on_disconnect`  annotation is not configuring the "tenacity"
retry library wait. The default is "no wait". Therefore, the retries
have a bigger chance of being affected by very minor instabilities
(microseconds connection issues can generate a problem with this
configuration). One alternative to avoid such problems in the future
is to use a wait configuration such as the one being proposed. Then,
ceilometer computer pollsters would wait/sleep before retrying, which
would provide some time for the system to be available for the compute
pollsters.

In this proposal, we would wait 2^x * 3 seconds between each retry
starting with 1 second, then up to 60 seconds.

Change-Id: I9a2d46f870dc2d2791a7763177773dc0cf8aed9d

commit_message:
Make code compatible with SQLAlchemy 1.4.18

Also, plugins do not need to enable any network service other than what
devstack is already doing [1].

Also, fix doc build:
- bump up tox minversion to 3.18
- set ignore_basepython_conflict to True [2]
- add tex-gyre to binddep.txt [3]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/791436
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/a0ec2de968cfded8b88c2f3af1152b5932d675b7/tox.ini#L7
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-health/+/793984

Change-Id: Ib6e3ed40dc8b075c3cecb967b7417097e3cab60d
Co-authored-by: Ghanshyam Mann <gmann@ghanshyammann.com>

subject: Project Stopwatch
messages:
[{'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-04-10 07:32:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-04-10 14:10:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

While I think the model is quite neat, and could help some teams, it seems to me too strict. I would prefer we become more liberal rather than less, perhaps suggesting models like this but not mandating them.

In terms of a coordinated release, what IMO we're looking for is a release that downstream consumers can consume at a reasonable cadence, knowing that it will be stable and maintained for a period of time.

I would rather see a simple, liberal model where teams are free to release as they wish, and periodically one recent release will be promoted to a stable release, for inclusion in a coordinated OpenStack release. A branch would be cut at that point for patch releases."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-04-12 08:36:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> While I think the model is quite neat, and could help some teams,
 > it seems to me too strict. I would prefer we become more liberal
 > rather than less, perhaps suggesting models like this but not
 > mandating them.
 > 
 > In terms of a coordinated release, what IMO we're looking for is a
 > release that downstream consumers can consume at a reasonable
 > cadence, knowing that it will be stable and maintained for a period
 > of time.
 > 
 > I would rather see a simple, liberal model where teams are free to
 > release as they wish, and periodically one recent release will be
 > promoted to a stable release, for inclusion in a coordinated
 > OpenStack release. A branch would be cut at that point for patch
 > releases.

That sounds to me like the description of the "independent" part in this proposal. Basically extending the current "independent" tooling would allow the flexibility the projects need.

This takes a conservative approach for projects which need the conservative approach.

I agree that "being more lax" is probably the way to go forward.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2020-04-15 13:27:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The proposal is based on the predicate that having a feature freeze every 6 months puts too much pressure on getting things in the coordinated release (the one that has a stable branch). The issue is that the solution presented still has a special feature freeze every 6 months to get things in the coordinated release (the one that has a stable branch). There will still be one too-important-to-miss feature freeze every 6 months, just like today. So I fail to see how adding less-important feature freezes every 2 months is going to reduce pressure and work. 

This proposal is also based on the idea that you simplify by proposing only two models: one very constrained tick-tock model (with much more constraints than the current cycle-with-rc model), and the independent model for those who can't have that many constraints (or do not produce anything in 4 months, which is now quite common). The issue I have with this is that the "independent" model is... independent of the coordinated cycle. It means that deliverables under that model do not produce stable branches every cycle, and that they are not tested together with other deliverables using the same cycle-based stable branches. That's why we currently enforce that all OpenStack "IaaS" services follow the release model tied to the cycle (can't be independent). I feel that pushing services to use an independent model would be a significant regression.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-04-16 09:23:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I would rather see a simple, liberal model where teams are free to release as they wish, and periodically one recent release will be promoted to a stable release, for inclusion in a coordinated OpenStack release. A branch would be cut at that point for patch releases.

I was thinking among the same lines: a bunch of releases, some of them spawning semi-stable branches (at the discretion of a team). And a final coordinated release of all projects once a year with long-term support.

I haven't read the proposal in question yet, answering the comments first (yes, I'm weird)."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-04-16 11:54:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > I would rather see a simple, liberal model where teams are free
 > to release as they wish, and periodically one recent release will
 > be promoted to a stable release, for inclusion in a coordinated
 > OpenStack release. A branch would be cut at that point for patch
 > releases.
 > 
 > I was thinking among the same lines: a bunch of releases, some of
 > them spawning semi-stable branches (at the discretion of a team).
 > And a final coordinated release of all projects once a year with
 > long-term support.
 > 
 > I haven't read the proposal in question yet, answering the comments
 > first (yes, I'm weird).

That's kinda where I am headed with the 'independent' part of the model.
People can spawn up their branches, do their tagging. The release team deals with the tooling and consistent expectations for users.

However, the independent model still stays out of the "coordinated release" in my example. This is because I trust CI to be a better contract of coordination than anything else really. So for me, I want to move, in the future to claim that the coordinated release is merely a tag on top of independent deliverables (which can be asserted by CI basically).'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-04-16 12:02:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> The proposal is based on the predicate that having a feature freeze
 > every 6 months puts too much pressure on getting things in the
 > coordinated release (the one that has a stable branch).

That's correct, it's an issue I heard many times.

 > The issue
 > is that the solution presented still has a special feature freeze
 > every 6 months to get things in the coordinated release (the one
 > that has a stable branch).

It does not require a big major feature freeze, nor have the checkpoints.
People can still work on features. It imposes a rythm to the contributors to avoid a burnout effect.

 > There will still be one
 > too-important-to-miss feature freeze every 6 months, just like
 > today. So I fail to see how adding less-important feature freezes
 > every 2 months is going to reduce pressure and work.

It forces the community to think differently about freezes, and that's one of the gaps we have to fight, IMO.

 > 
 > This proposal is also based on the idea that you simplify by
 > proposing only two models: one very constrained tick-tock model
 > (with much more constraints than the current cycle-with-rc model),
 > and the independent model for those who can't have that many
 > constraints (or do not produce anything in 4 months, which is now
 > quite common). The issue I have with this is that the "independent"
 > model is... independent of the coordinated cycle.

Do you think it would make sense to drop the tick-tock, and just go for independent for everyone?

 > It means that
 > deliverables under that model do not produce stable branches every
 > cycle, and that they are not tested together with other
 > deliverables using the same cycle-based stable branches.

Asserting to be one or the other doesn't change how testing is made, isn't it?
That was the whole point of the tick-tock model: We force some kind of cadence, to have a migration path forward to independent deliverables which have a way to ensure co-installability.

 > That's why
 > we currently enforce that all OpenStack "IaaS" services follow the
 > release model tied to the cycle (can't be independent). I feel that
 > pushing services to use an independent model would be a significant
 > regression.

I am pretty sure this model won't please everyone. However, I am trying to move and change things, where it doesn't seem to work.

This proposal intends to be more flexible in terms of releasing, improving the freedom of the projects, and provides a path to ensure co-installability that _at the same time_ could reduce the pressure on PTLs. 

All suggestions (or improvements) on this are welcome :)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-04-16 12:03:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> However, the independent model still stays out of the "coordinated release" in my example.

Well, this means that ironic would stay out of the coordinated release, which is something that people are trying to avoid, as far as I understand.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-04-16 12:07:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > However, the independent model still stays out of the
 > "coordinated release" in my example.
 > 
 > Well, this means that ironic would stay out of the coordinated
 > release, which is something that people are trying to avoid, as far
 > as I understand.

I am fine with ironic being out of the coordinated release tbh.
What I would be less fine/more sad is ironic getting out of the OpenStack project for a wrong reason ;)

It's different to be part of the coordinated release and be an official project. I can discuss that in another media than this review though :)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-04-16 12:12:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't see what will be left of ironic's participation in OpenStack if we even stop being parts of coordinated releases (and thus e.g. gate against other components in the same way we do now)."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-04-17 07:11:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I don't see what will be left of ironic's participation in
 > OpenStack if we even stop being parts of coordinated releases (and
 > thus e.g. gate against other components in the same way we do now).

You would still be an openstack project. It means that Ironic _can_ still be co-tested/integrated easily, but also:
- Ensures you're following the PTI (this way you won't break non-standalone users)
- Ensures you have a consistent user interface with other projects
- Ensure you can benefit from the tooling from the rest of the community, like releases, infra, etc.

It makes me real sad to see we are at a point where people don't see the value of being an official OpenStack project. This is dividing instead of multipling. But I will shut up now, I am probably an old fart :p"}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-04-17 08:11:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sorry, but I have to disagree on all three points:

> Ensures you're following the PTI (this way you won't break non-standalone users)

This is ensured by our general sanity, not by our membership in OpenStack.

> Ensures you have a consistent user interface with other projects

Literally nothing ensures this right now. API SIG has never received enough traction, there is no consistency effort for OSC plugins, microvesions did not become universal (nor neutron-style extensions) and only openstacksdk is trying, but there is no global move to replace clients with it.

> Ensure you can benefit from the tooling from the rest of the community, like releases, infra, etc.

We'd still use the same infra, only some of the releases tooling would be missing (and for independent projects it's of little help anyway)."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-04-17 14:29:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Sorry, but I have to disagree on all three points:

That makes it an interesting conversation, isn't it? :p 

 > 
 > > Ensures you're following the PTI (this way you won't break
 > non-standalone users)
 > 
 > This is ensured by our general sanity, not by our membership in
 > OpenStack.

I don't disagree that sanity makes us chose the versions, but the membership in openstack ensures it. That's why the PTI was meant for. But yeah, it's about a set of expectations, not code.

 > 
 > > Ensures you have a consistent user interface with other projects
 > 
 > Literally nothing ensures this right now. API SIG has never
 > received enough traction, there is no consistency effort for OSC
 > plugins, microvesions did not become universal (nor neutron-style
 > extensions) and only openstacksdk is trying, but there is no global
 > move to replace clients with it.

There was multiple efforts (and there are still continued efforts) to have OSC as the single consistent CLI.
I agree it has limited success. But it is probably more consistent than if it was the wild west, don't you think?

 > 
 > > Ensure you can benefit from the tooling from the rest of the
 > community, like releases, infra, etc.
 > 
 > We'd still use the same infra, only some of the releases tooling
 > would be missing (and for independent projects it's of little help
 > anyway).

My proposal highlights the benefits for the independent model.

I think that now we are discussing the fundamentals of the idea.
Should we merge the idea as it is right now, and just iterate over it, by mentioning that this was proposed and not really well accepted? I have the impression if we do it, we're gonna be able to improve the idea to match what more folks are needing."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-06-18 10:05:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-08-06 09:10:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think we can merge that.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-08-06 09:12:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-08-06 09:13:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I am merging the idea.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-08-07 14:20:13.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Workflow+1 by Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe@evrard.me>
'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-08-07 14:20:22.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review+2 by Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe@evrard.me>
'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2021-04-19 11:56:47.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Thierry Carrez.'}, {'account_id': 30523, 'date': '2021-06-30 10:33:08.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Dincer Celik.'}]

commit_message:
Project Stopwatch

This is a proposal to change our release cycles, simplifying
our procedures.

Change-Id: I1875855e8accfbb7ff64af1781f0856c12760c11

commit_message:
Default Heat images to container image prepare defaults

Use the defaults from container image prepare to set the default values
for the standalone and undercloud heat api and engine images. This will
allow the default upstream or downstream defaults from the right branch
to be used.

Additionally this patch splits out the ephemeral heat containers to a
special namespace and tag that we use in THT to setup the containers for
the overcloud deploy command on an undercloud.

related-bug: 1931995
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/796617
Change-Id: I55fb9816e2b0a54717938b7a094bde6780811305
Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Alex Schultz <aschultz@redhat.com>

commit_message:
[OVN] Add binding-extended to the ML2_SUPPORTED_API_EXTENSIONS

This extension should be enabled with ML2/OVN backend also but
recent changes in how supported extensions are calculated ([1])
it was filtered out.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/793141

Closes-Bug: #1933954
Change-Id: Ic8ab322683e72101a8f797b108bf23bc169092cb

commit_message:
Introducing the oslo_config_validator role

This role is intended to leverage the `oslo-config-validator` on each one
of the configuration files found on a deployment. The goal is to quickly
catch erroneous configurations.

When called manually, it will also be possible to generate a report
returning all the differences between the current configuration and the
default configuration

One last thing, it will also validate the values of some specific
settings, based on the invalid_settings dict in the configuration.
Because of that, we moved some checks in nova_event_callback to the
oslo_config_validator role.

NOTE(dvd): Removing backup-and-restore group from this branch as it's
not available prior to Wallaby.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.config/+/794815
Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1940815
Resolves: rhbz#1940815
Change-Id: Id047fe378cf512b985c9d7478a991f11b280102b
(cherry picked from commit 4aaca32f19af6426a6f1eb6ea896e8d10458928d)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-09 17:51:03.000000000', 'message': "Use TCP keepalives for ovsdb connections

When failing over OVN DB servers from one server to another, the
server which originally hosted the VIP doesn't notice the connection
is gone and doesn't reconnect. Ultimately, this is something that
needs to be fixed in python-ovs, but setting the SO_KEEPALIVE socket
option avoids the issue. This also has the benefit that the client
doesn't need to send 'echo' requests, which can time out on an
overloaded ovsdb-server, which causes a disconnection which then
adds even more load on the ovsdb-server as it has to send the entire
db contents over the wire after the connection.

Closes-Bug: #1930926
Change-Id: Ie0205785cab307c132fbe409588739685cade7c0
(cherry picked from neutron commit 65cce351d74a9a637fdb2a9d5e0e63445dda9ea9)

commit_message:
Use TCP keepalives for ovsdb connections

When failing over OVN DB servers from one server to another, the
server which originally hosted the VIP doesn't notice the connection
is gone and doesn't reconnect. Ultimately, this is something that
needs to be fixed in python-ovs, but setting the SO_KEEPALIVE socket
option avoids the issue. This also has the benefit that the client
doesn't need to send 'echo' requests, which can time out on an
overloaded ovsdb-server, which causes a disconnection which then
adds even more load on the ovsdb-server as it has to send the entire
db contents over the wire after the connection.

Closes-Bug: #1930926
Change-Id: Ie0205785cab307c132fbe409588739685cade7c0
(cherry picked from neutron commit 65cce351d74a9a637fdb2a9d5e0e63445dda9ea9)

commit_message:
debian: add support

This patch updates the meta to reflect it's support
of Debian accordingly as well as rename ubuntu vars
file to debian.

Change-Id: I3f4c4a66e11109c32144216b9c5617260b158ac4

commit_message:
Test bundles for focal-wallaby and hirsute-wallaby

These are the test bundles (and any associated changes) for
focal-wallaby and hirsute-wallaby support.

hisute-wallaby test is disabled (moved to dev) due to [1].

[1] https://github.com/juju-solutions/layer-basic/issues/194

Change-Id: I1fcee89725686c2f1ff061f8964ee5ef8b7e09a2

commit_message:
Add errors.txt in artcl_logstash_files

Removing duplicate .txt extension from errors.txt..

Also, Adding errors.txt in artcl_logstash_files so that logstash pick
this up.

As size of logstash file is a factor, Adding errors.txt instead of
individual files seems better approach as errors.txt only contains
error/traceback from different log files.

Change-Id: Ib4519943d6b0ca4607f168318dff11a6d1713796

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-17 20:47:51.000000000', 'message': 'LVM: Use --readonly for lvdisplay and Retry call on segfault

This is a follow-up to I0a2420f3e4a411f5fa52ebe2d22859b138ef387f.

LVM commands segfault occasionally, exiting with code 139.
Change I6824ba4f introduced a workaround to retry the command
when code 139 is returned, which generally works.  This expands
that retry to the case where thin pool space is queried, which
currently results in the LVM driver reporting no free space to
the scheduler.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/796889
Closes-Bug: #1932364
Change-Id: I7c0f4d4ea7de635afede3c8514a5da9e85ad9b48

commit_message:
LVM: Retry lvdisplay and lvcreate calls on segfault

This is a follow-up to I0a2420f3e4a411f5fa52ebe2d22859b138ef387f.

LVM commands segfault occasionally, exiting with code 139.
Change I6824ba4f introduced a workaround to retry the command
when code 139 is returned, which generally works.

Closes-Bug: #1932188
Change-Id: I7c0f4d4ea7de635afede3c8514a5da9e85ad9b48

commit_message:
Revert "Remove the idle_timeout option."

This reverts commit a857b83c9c28d1fe461d1c06549607c48acf337b. We will
reintroduce this as part of a future 10.0.0 release.

Change-Id: Ie8ec9f1dafd52d78f5676f89434514069759207b
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Introducing the oslo_config_validator role

This role is intended to leverage the `oslo-config-validator` on each one
of the configuration files found on a deployment. The goal is to quickly
catch erroneous configurations.

When called manually, it will also be possible to generate a report
returning all the differences between the current configuration and the
default configuration

One last thing, it will also validate the values of some specific
settings, based on the invalid_settings dict in the configuration.
Because of that, we moved some checks in nova_event_callback to the
oslo_config_validator role.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.config/+/790883
Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1940815
Resolves: rhbz#1940815
Change-Id: Id047fe378cf512b985c9d7478a991f11b280102b
(cherry picked from commit 4aaca32f19af6426a6f1eb6ea896e8d10458928d)

commit_message:
Replace "split(' ')" with "split()" in masakari-monitors

By default, if split's step is None, runs of consecutive whitespace
are regarded as a single separator. So there is no need to use
split(' ').

Change-Id: Idcda8dfcaf5fd5abfab106238f91acdd3166883f

Currently some http endpoints like glance don't have httplog enabled
thus all access logs in haproxy doesn't include L7 information but only
L4 information.
This change ensures that httplog is enabled for all http endpoints so
that L7 infomation is recorded in haproxy.log.

Closes-Bug: #1930266
Change-Id: Ia98657707adb9c9ec8e0bb7b01931e2bc4997e1d
(cherry picked from commit 1a0b513423c378cc13ec982e5cb07ac87f0821e3)

commit_message:
haproxy: Enable httplog for all http endpoints

Currently some http endpoints like glance don't have httplog enabled
thus all access logs in haproxy doesn't include L7 information but only
L4 information.
This change ensures that httplog is enabled for all http endpoints so
that L7 infomation is recorded in haproxy.log.

Closes-Bug: #1930266
Change-Id: Ia98657707adb9c9ec8e0bb7b01931e2bc4997e1d
(cherry picked from commit 1a0b513423c378cc13ec982e5cb07ac87f0821e3)

This role is intended to leverage the `oslo-config-validator` on each one
of the configuration files found on a deployment. The goal is to quickly
catch erroneous configurations.

When called manually, it will also be possible to generate a report
returning all the differences between the current configuration and the
default configuration

One last thing, it will also validate the values of some specific
settings, based on the invalid_settings dict in the configuration.
Because of that, we moved some checks in nova_event_callback to the
oslo_config_validator role.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.config/+/790883
Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1940815
Resolves: rhbz#1940815

When called manually, it will also be possible to generate a report

oslo_config_validator role.

commit_message:
Introducing the oslo_config_validator role

This role is intended to leverage the `oslo-config-validator` on each one
of the configuration files found on a deployment. The goal is to quickly
catch erroneous configurations.

When called manually, it will also be possible to generate a report
returning all the differences between the current configuration and the
default configuration

One last thing, it will also validate the values of some specific
settings, based on the invalid_settings dict in the configuration.
Because of that, we moved some checks in nova_event_callback to the
oslo_config_validator role.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.config/+/790883
Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1940815
Resolves: rhbz#1940815
Change-Id: Id047fe378cf512b985c9d7478a991f11b280102b

commit_message:
Add act-stdby scenario jobs to the gate

The active-standby scenario jobs have been stable to the point we feel
comfortable to promote them to voting jobs. These jobs test
active-standby amphora load balancers which is the recommended topology
for production deployments.

This change also consolidates the single and two-node active-standby
jobs to run both the active-standby and full scenario suites.

https://zuul.openstack.org/builds?job_name=octavia-v2-act-stdby-dsvm-scenario-two-node

[{'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2020-11-03 11:34:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-11-03 12:00:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2020-11-03 12:21:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Sean, I'll push that fix later on after feedback from CI. I also got a question regarding this change, since we are applying this fix manually downstream and are determined to try to upstream all our changes. What is the possibility of backporting simple features or improvements like this? Considering it is 1) adding a feature 2) still backward compatible and 3) includes full testing"}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-11-03 12:25:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> ... What is the possibility of backporting simple
 > features or improvements like this? Considering it is 1) adding a
 > feature 2) still backward compatible and 3) includes full testing

Backporting new config options isn't usually allowed with stable policy. But I think we may be able to consider this a bugfix - let's see what other people think. If it does fix a bug, then since it is backwards compatible with the default value not changing existing behavior, I think it would be safe.

It could help to file a bug to capture what the problem is with not having this capability. Then you can update the commit message with a line that has "Closes-bug: #[bugnumber]". That would make it more obvious that this is addressing an issue and therefore something we may want to consider backporting.'}, {'account_id': 26537, 'date': '2020-11-03 12:35:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2020-12-16 15:43:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Sorry this has been sitting so long.  I left some comments on the other patch for you: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/746025/

I think if you rework the patch to take those into account, this will be fine.  Also, note Sean's suggestion about making this a bugfix (and hence backportable).  I think we should proceed with this patch if you're still interested in contributing the fix; the author of the other patch has still not responded."}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2021-01-12 14:41:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2021-01-12 14:41:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2021-01-12 14:44:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

This now takes a new approach and renames the configuration option to backup_swift_create_storage_policy. It will only try to create the container if it doesn't exist (does a HEAD request to check if container exists before).

If it already exists and the storage policy is different than the configured one we log a warning. I'm not sure if we want that thought. Consider the use-case if somebody wants to change the configured storage policy and understands that the old containers will be the old storage policy unless deleted we would log a warning each time which could spam the log, seems kind of bad?

You can ignore the testing for now, I haven't updated it yet."}, {'account_id': 26537, 'date': '2021-01-12 16:14:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Cinder Windows CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Cinder Windows CI

- cinder-smb http://cloudbase-ci.com/cinder/761113/6/smb/ : SUCCESS in 1h 02m 28s'}, {'account_id': 28801, 'date': '2021-01-12 17:31:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

- dsvm-tempest-cisco-zonemanager-job http://173.39.89.136/logs/13/761113/6/check/dsvm-tempest-cisco-zonemanager-job/5654281/ : SUCCESS in 1h 16m 45s'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-01-14 01:59:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> If it already exists and the storage policy is different than the configured one we log a warning. I'm not sure if we want that thought. Consider the use-case if somebody wants to change the configured storage policy and understands that the old containers will be the old storage policy unless deleted we would log a warning each time which could spam the log, seems kind of bad?

I'll defer to your judgement on this.  The config option is a blunt instrument, so the use case you outline seems extremely plausible.  I guess debug-level is fine as long as the help text for the option makes it clear that the policy only applies to new swift containers and is ignored for already existing containers."}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2021-03-30 15:37:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 28801, 'date': '2021-03-30 23:39:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

commit_message:
Add backup_swift_create_storage_policy config opt

This configuration option is used by the Swift backup
driver to select the storage policy to use when creating
the container used to store backups.

It defaults to None meaning the default behavior is
preserved.

Change-Id: I0a4a9d4e099c7d4a1d209be28ade5a517aeb96df

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-29 12:46:32.000000000', 'message': "WIP Workaround for ML2/OVN bad reply on SG rule deletion

Since devstack moved to ML2/OVN, we have had a high number
of failures in CI because delete_security_group_rule returns
a Conflict exception while the message explicitly says that
the SG rule doesn't exist.
Catch the Conflict exception when deleting SG rule until
the bug (lp#1933638) is fixed in neutron or ML2/OVN.

Change-Id: Ib4a82fc2452f4f5a56baf1bc8aa3c15d4daa9b47
Story: 2009002
Task: 42668
"}]
commit_message:
WIP Workaround for ML2/OVN bad reply on SG rule deletion

Since devstack moved to ML2/OVN, we have had a high number
of failures in CI because delete_security_group_rule returns
a Conflict exception while the message explicitly says that
the SG rule doesn't exist.
Catch the Conflict exception when deleting SG rule until
the bug (lp#1933638) is fixed in neutron or ML2/OVN.

Change-Id: Ib4a82fc2452f4f5a56baf1bc8aa3c15d4daa9b47
Story: 2009002
Task: 42668

commit_message:
Delete the gluster_used_vols collection variable

The volume usage of gluster is recorded by the drivers_private_data
database. In a multi-file sharing backend environment,
'self.gluster_used_vols' There is no need to implement the function
of glusterfs volume usage. This work is undertaken by
drivers_private_data. After changing the code, it is only used as
a normal variable

Closes-Bug: #1922177

Change-Id: I3f3eb01a56cc6ac3bf27ff7bd8ac8393417d9578

commit_message:
Fix ObjectChangeHandler thread usage

Instead of spawning new thread for each OVO change,
keep one long running thread fetching changes
from queue.

Closes-Bug: #1926417
Change-Id: I390cabeaf6ebbc1c6206fe2cc226ef437462c7fd

[{'created': '2021-05-04 14:52:58.000000000', 'message': 'Update tox.ini for tripleo-docs

Removes the pep8 and bindep tox environments. pep8 did not run
successfully as there is no test-requirements.txt file, and there is
nothing to test anyway. bindep also has nothing to test, so it's also
removed.

The deploy-guide tox environment is added to the default list so that
just running "tox" results in a full build of the documentation
including the user and deploy guide.

Change-Id: I1990556fec47905d2e137b51bcaefd15fe597dea
'}]
commit_message:
Update tox.ini for tripleo-docs

Removes the pep8 and bindep tox environments. pep8 did not run
successfully as there is no test-requirements.txt file, and there is
nothing to test anyway. bindep also has nothing to test, so it's also
removed.

The deploy-guide tox environment is added to the default list so that
just running "tox" results in a full build of the documentation
including the user and deploy guide.

Change-Id: I1990556fec47905d2e137b51bcaefd15fe597dea

commit_message:
Correct the tox option for skipping sdist generation

The tox option to skip source distribution building is skipsdist,
but this seems to be often misspelled skipdist instead, which gets
silently ignored and so does not take effect. Correct it
everywhere, in hopes that new projects will finally stop copying
this mistake around.

See https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-skipsdist
and https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/issues/1388 for details.

Change-Id: Ie0667de615e02284cb6302d9df7165651a16f988

subject: Add support for the http frontend.
messages:
[{'account_id': 26032, 'date': '2020-07-10 04:28:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2020-07-13 05:23:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Generally this looks OK - please add bundles for releases which should support the beast frontend to ensure test coverage.

There is an additional complexity in that the beast frontend is also not supported on all architectures - this needs to be represented in the enablement.'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2020-07-13 05:23:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21107, 'date': '2020-08-04 09:11:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The architecture situation seems a little complicated.. beast depends on boost-context which wasn't supported on S390 in the past but it was added in mid-2019 by https://github.com/boostorg/context/pull/117 and a bunch of other PRs. 

This seems to exist in Focal which has a boost-context package for s390x (and various patches for improving its performance), however, the Ceph package is still explicitly setting WITH_BOOST_CONTEXT=off based on what is (I think) an out of date architecture list. 

So we'll likely need to fix the ceph package to build on s390x and any other architectures we care about (and test it actually works), and then codify some kind of matrix into the charm about when this might be supported. Which will depend both on the version and architecture since beast will likely end up available earlier on x86_64 than s390x.

It would be good to know which architectures we care about in the charms, is this documented somewhere?"}, {'account_id': 26032, 'date': '2020-08-05 04:39:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 26032, 'date': '2020-08-05 04:40:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 26032, 'date': '2021-06-30 00:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Done in change 789825'}]

commit_message:
Add support for the http frontend.

This adds support for configuring the 'beast' frontend for ceph's rados gateway.
This is to maintain feature parity with upstream ceph.
Some comparison tests suggest beast performs better in scale out deployments than civetweb, and upstream documentation
suggests it will be the focus of future development.

Change-Id: Iafcbefd0dbee7c499056276370c61e9e0e8e9d41
Closes-Bug: #1865396

commit_message:
Improvements to zone blacklist doc

Replaced http api calls with openstack client commands.
Note blacklist exception policy for admin users.
Changed voicing to be more passive
Blacklists only apply to zones, not records.

Change-Id: I7f3662c57ee9bccb42381134523e8fdd21e93740

commit_message:
Upgrade oslo.db version

oslo.db 9.1.0 extends capabilities to handle changes
in duplicate key error information introduced since
MySQL 8.0.19 and fixes issue arose during inspection
of node created with idrac driver, inspect interface
as idrac-redfish.

Story: 2008901
Task: 42468
Change-Id: Ic18e485d4eb14566554d25379a719669ac362d70

commit_message:
Migrate back haproxy validation to tripleo-validations

This patch moves back the haproxy validation from validations-common to
tripleo-validations. It has been renamed in tripleo-haproxy and the role
is called now tripleo_haproxy.

This patch also fix the host targeting in order to only execute this
validation on nodes where haproxy is really installed and configured.

Note that the haproxy validations hosted in validations-common will be
removed in a follow up patch.

Closes-Bug: #1926024

Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <michele@redhat.com>

Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I9869afd60342fdb0aca69a313c1c6e35e0947fb8
